content:
I have the below in a LaTeX file in the FLT repo:

\begin{definition}\label{Frey_package}\lean{FLT.FreyPackage}\leanok A \emph{Frey package} is a ...

and in particular I use \emph{foo} to clarify that I am defining foo. This works fine in the pdf version of the blueprint

Screenshot-from-2024-03-23-14-45-10.png

in the sense that "Frey Package" is in a different font. But in the PlasTeX version the words are not emphasized:

Screenshot-from-2024-03-23-14-46-03.png

What should I be doing here? It is a pet hate of mine to see definitions in manuscripts where the term being defined doesn't stand out in some way.
You could use bold instead. Alternatively this is probably fixable in CSS once I can see the code :)
I bet the issue is that the whole text of a definition is in italics (which contradicts amstex \theoremstyle{definition})
@Kevin Buzzard what happens if you use \theoremstyle{definition} before \newtheorem{definition}{Definition} in your latex file?

Ruben Van de Velde said:

You could use bold instead. Alternatively this is probably fixable in CSS once I can see the code :)

I thought the point of \emph was "guarantees a change of font style". I'm going public in April; I would like to have a nice-looking blueprint graph before I do, so now term is over I'm pushing to get a bunch of blueprint material up.

Adam Topaz said:

Kevin Buzzard what happens if you use \theoremstyle{definition} before \newtheorem{definition}{Definition} in your latex file?

I seem to have a file blueprint/src/macro/web.tex containing

% Those macros are used for the web version of the blueprint.

\newtheorem{theorem}{Theorem}[chapter]
\newtheorem{definition}[theorem]{Definition}
\newtheorem{proposition}[theorem]{Proposition}
\newtheorem{lemma}[theorem]{Lemma}
\newtheorem{sublemma}[theorem]{Sub-lemma}
\newtheorem{corollary}[theorem]{Corollary}
\newtheorem{remark}[theorem]{Remark}
\newtheorem{example}[theorem]{Example}

What do you suggest that this file should look like?

I'm afraid I'm one of those people who writes papers in LaTeX by just taking the last paper they wrote in LaTeX, leaving the 500+ line long preamble containing a bunch of stuff they don't understand (written by a coauthor about 15 years ago), deleting the mathematical content and then populating the file with new mathematical content.

\newtheorem{theorem}{Theorem}[chapter]
\newtheorem{proposition}[theorem]{Proposition}
\newtheorem{lemma}[theorem]{Lemma}
\newtheorem{sublemma}[theorem]{Sub-lemma}
\newtheorem{corollary}[theorem]{Corollary}

\theoremstyle{definition}
\newtheorem{definition}[theorem]{Definition}

\theoremstyle{remark}
\newtheorem{remark}[theorem]{Remark}
\newtheorem{example}[theorem]{Example}
but note that this will change the formatting of definitions, remarks and exampls.
namely definitions will have a boldface "Definition", and unitalicized text. examples and remarks will have "Example" in italics, and unitalicized text.

Ruben Van de Velde said:

Alternatively this is probably fixable in CSS once I can see the code :)

To elaborate: LaTeX normally treats doubly-italicised text as not italicized. CSS can do this too, but it is not the default thing to do and you have to ask for it with emph emph { font-style: normal } or similar.
(I don't know if CSS can do this for arbitrary nesting, but you can add more rules to the desired depth)
